contextId.information: Here Asahel is compared to a gazelle, an animal that runs very fast. AT: "Asahel could run very fast" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: Asahel was swift in his feet like a wild gazelle

contextId.information: This refers to the closeness of this man and his little lamb. AT: "he loved it as much as if it were one of his daughters" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: was like a daughter to him

contextId.information: Here the woman speaks of a person dying as if they were water being spilled on the ground. AT: "We all must die, and after we die we cannot be brought back to life again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: For we all must die, and we are like water spilled on the ground ... up again

contextId.information: Here David, the king, is compared to an "angel of God." AT: "for the king is like an angel of God because they both know how to tell good from evil" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: for as an angel of God, so is my master ... from evil

contextId.information: The woman compares David's wisdom to the wisdom of an angel to emphasize how very wise he is. AT: "you are very wise, like an angel of God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: is wise, like the wisdom of an angel of God

contextId.information: Here the speaker is making a solemn promise. He compare the certainty the he will fulfill his promise to the certainty that Yahweh and the king are alive. AT: "I solemnly promise that as surely as Yahweh and the king live" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: As Yahweh lives, and as my master the king lives

contextId.information: Here Ahithophel speaks of the peoples' happiness by comparing it to a bride's happiness. AT: "and they will come happily, like a bride is happy when she comes to her husband" or "and they will come happily" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like a bride coming to her husband

contextId.information: The anger of the soldiers here is being compared to that of a mother bear who cubs are taken from her. AT: "they are angry, like a mother bear whose cubs have been take from her" or "they are very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: they are like a bear robbed of her cubs

contextId.information: Absalom's army is described as covering David's army like the dew covers the ground in the morning. AT: "we will overwhelm and completely defeat David's army" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: we will cover him as the dew falls on the ground

contextId.information: The watchman compares the way the man ran to the way Ahimaaz runs to suggest that it may be him. AT: "I think the man running in front is Ahimaaz son Zadok, because he runs like Ahimaaz" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: I think the running of the man in front is like the running of Ahimaaz son of Zadok

contextId.information: The Cushite uses a comparison as a polite way to tell the king that Absalom is dead. This can be stated more directly. AT: "I would like all your enemies ... to die the way that young man died" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
contextId.quote: The enemies of my master the king, ... should be as that young man is

contextId.information: The author compares the way that the soldiers had to sneak back into the city to the way that soldiers sneak away when they are running away from battle. This emphasizes that they were made to feel ashamed. AT: "in the same way that people who had run away from battle would sneak away because they were ashamed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: like people who are ashamed sneak away when they run from battle

contextId.information: When a person was weaving a cloth he would run the threads through hooks attached to large sticks called a "weaver's beam." This means Goliath's spear was larger than a normal spear. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]])
contextId.quote: whose spear was like a weaver's beam

contextId.information: This means that David completely destroyed his enemies. These two phrases "like dust on the ground" and "like mud on the streets" have a similar meaning and are used for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: like dust on the ground ... like mud in the streets

contextId.information: Here God is comparing the king to the morning light and sunshine after the rain. These are all ways of saying this king would be a delight to God and a blessing for the people. These two phrases have a similar meaning and are used for emphasis. AT: "He will be a delight to all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
contextId.quote: He will be like the morning light ... sunshine after rain

contextId.information: Here the wicked person is compared to useless thorns. This can be stated in active form. AT: "But the wicked person is worthless and dangerous like thorns we throw away" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_simile]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
contextId.quote: But the worthless will all be like thorns to be thrown away
